S2.T1.caption: Table 1: The expected errors using uniform federation of players in each coalition when all three players have 5 samples each, with parameters μe=10,σ2=1formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑒10superscript𝜎21\mu_{e}=10,\sigma^{2}=1. Each row denotes a different coalition partition: for example, {a,b}​{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b\}\{c\} indicates that players a𝑎a and b𝑏b are federating together while c𝑐c is alone.
S2.T1.table:
Coalition structure e​r​ra​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑎⋅err_{a}(\cdot) e​r​rb​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑏⋅err_{b}(\cdot) e​r​rc​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑐⋅err_{c}(\cdot)
{a},{b},{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a\},\{b\},\{c\} 2 2 2
{a,b},{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b\},\{c\} 1.5 1.5 2
{a,b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b,c\} 1.3 1.3 1.3
references: First, we will analyze uniform federation, with three players, a,b,𝑎𝑏a,b, and c𝑐c. We will first assume that each player has 5 samples from their local data distribution: Table 1 gives the error each player can expect in this situation. Arrangements equivalent up to renaming of players are omitted. Every player sees its error minimized in the “grand coalition” πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} where all three players are federating together. This implies that the only arrangement that is stable (core-stable or individually stable) is πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g}.

Thirdly, we will assume that all three players have 25 samples: this example is shown in Table 3. As in Table 1, the players have identical preferences. However, in this case, the players minimize their error by being alone. Overall, stability results from this example are part of a broader pattern we will analyze in later sections.

S2.T2.caption: Table 2: The expected errors using uniform federation of players in each coalition when players a𝑎a and b𝑏b have 5 samples each and player c𝑐c has 25 samples, with parameters μe=10,σ2=1formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑒10superscript𝜎21\mu_{e}=10,\sigma^{2}=1.
S2.T2.table:
Coalition structure e​r​ra​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑎⋅err_{a}(\cdot) e​r​rb​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑏⋅err_{b}(\cdot) e​r​rc​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑐⋅err_{c}(\cdot)
{a},{b},{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a\},\{b\},\{c\} 2 2 0.4
{a,b},{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b\},\{c\} 1.5 1.5 0.4
{a},{b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a\},\{b,c\} 2 1.72 0.39
{a,b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b,c\} 1.55 1.55 0.41
references: Next, we assume that player c𝑐c increases the amount of samples it has from 5 to 25: Table 2 demonstrates the error each player can expect in this situation. Here, the players have different preferences over which arrangement they would most prefer. The “small” players a𝑎a and b𝑏b would most prefer {a,b}​{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b\}\{c\}, whereas the “large” player c𝑐c would most prefer {a},{b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a\},\{b,c\} or (identically) {b},{a,c}𝑏𝑎𝑐\{b\},\{a,c\}. However out of all of these coalition structures, only {a,b},{c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b\},\{c\} is stable (either core stable or individually stable). Note that {a},{b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a\},\{b,c\} is not stable because the coalition C={a,b}𝐶𝑎𝑏C=\{a,b\} is one where each player prefers C𝐶C to its current situation.

references: Thirdly, we will assume that all three players have 25 samples: this example is shown in Table 3. As in Table 1, the players have identical preferences. However, in this case, the players minimize their error by being alone. Overall, stability results from this example are part of a broader pattern we will analyze in later sections.

S2.T4.caption: Table 4: The expected errors using optimal coarse-grained federation when players a,b,c𝑎𝑏𝑐a,b,c each have 30 samples, while player d𝑑d has 300 samples, with parameters μe=10,σ2=1formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑒10superscript𝜎21\mu_{e}=10,\sigma^{2}=1.
S2.T4.table:
Coalition structure e​r​ra​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑎⋅err_{a}(\cdot) e​r​rd​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑑⋅err_{d}(\cdot)
{a},{b},{c},{d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a\},\{b\},\{c\},\{d\} 0.333 0.0333
{a,b,c},{d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a,b,c\},\{d\} 0.278 0.0333
{a,b,c,d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a,b,c,d\} 0.280 0.0326
references: Table 4 shows an example using coarse federation with four players: three have 30 samples each, and the fourth player has 300 samples. We assume the weights wjsubscript𝑤𝑗w_{j} are set optimally for each player. For conciseness, some columns and rows are omitted. Note that both player types get lower error in πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} than they would with local learning: that is, πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} is individually stable (stable against defections of any player alone). However, it is also clear that πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} is not core stable: in particular, the three small players would get lower error in {a,b,c}𝑎𝑏𝑐\{a,b,c\} than in πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g}. These results will be examined theoretically in later sections: with optimal weighting, coarse-grained federation will always have an individually stable πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} that is not necessarily core stable.

S2.T5.caption: Table 5: The expected errors using optimal fine-grained federation when players a,b,c𝑎𝑏𝑐a,b,c each have 30 samples, while player d𝑑d has 300 samples, with parameters μe=10,σ2=1formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑒10superscript𝜎21\mu_{e}=10,\sigma^{2}=1.
S2.T5.table:
Coalition structure e​r​ra​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑎⋅err_{a}(\cdot) e​r​rd​(⋅)𝑒𝑟subscript𝑟𝑑⋅err_{d}(\cdot)
{a},{b},{c},{d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a\},\{b\},\{c\},\{d\} 0.333 0.0333
{a,b,c},{d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a,b,c\},\{d\} 0.278 0.0333
{a,b,c,d}𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑑\{a,b,c,d\} 0.269 0.0325
references: Finally, we examine fine-grained federation. Table 5 analyzes the same case as coarse-grained federation previously, but with optimally-weighted fine-grained federation. The full error table shows that πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} is core stable because each player minimizes their error in this arrangement. This result will hold theoretically: when optimal fine-grained federation is used, πgsubscript𝜋𝑔\pi_{g} always minimizes error for every player and is thus core stable.
